journal
March 13, 1852
Reason and judgment should be our guides.

Journal for 1852
The friends I leave behind me Adieu, My native land, adieu!
Though I must leave thee, yet I love thee, and my fond heart shall still be true. true to those that dwell within thee. where'er I roam, as far, or near.
Shall memory oft of thee remind me; My spirit still with linger here amid the friends I leave behind me. The home of my sires! beneath thy breast, lost one, too fondly loved, are sleeping' land of all lands on earth the best. I leave these treasures in thy keeping. Until this hour I never knew how strong the cords of love could bind me how dear the home I bid adieu. How dear the friends I leave behind me. My home, my native land, adieu! I'll bless thee ever, till I perish. shall I return, and shall I view again the forms of those I cherish? I cannot tell; yet this I know; whatever the lot of heaven assigned me, or life or death, or (weal) or woe, I'll bless the friends I leave behind me."
Holmes D Van Schaick

Journal 1852
to the rail road house. At (    ), we again took the cars and went to Manilius, thence on foot to Manlius Centre, to the house of MrF (F's father, where we put up for the night.
Tuesday (  ) + I arose at seven o clock and breakfasted at eight. After breakfast Mr F and I discussed the propriety of his going west with me. In consequence of some defect in his financial affairs, he concluded not to go. I consequently came to the same conclusion concerning myself. Having failed of going west I resolved to return home and wait the day appointed (Apr 5th) at three pm I again made my appearance at North Manilius (my home) I then unpacked a fraction of my clothes, and took my rifle and went in ( )'s woods hunting for crows, but found none. after a tramp of about an hour I returned, ate my supper, and soon after went to ()'s and stayed till near eight oclock. I then returned home. Thus closed the day. The weather during the day has been gloomy it snowed nearly all dy

Journal 1852
Monday March 22, 1852
I arose at an early hour and prepared to start for the auriferous regions. My fit-out consisted of a sachel filled with clothes and other necessary articles, an India rubber coat, a rifle, revolver (SC) All things being ready Brother (PJ) ordered (J) to harness and hitch his horses to the sleigh and convey himself and me to Keirkville, where we were to take the cars and go to Oneida where the company was to meet for J was going to see me start. The cars arrived and we went on board. Soon we reached Canastata where I saw friend Lewis who informed me that the company did not intend start that day in consequence of some disadvantage on the route. I ere left much disappointed.. I  however proceeded to Oneida where I found out the particulars concerning the company. During the day friend F and I went to old Oneida and back, we visited different party of New O, we went several times to a Daguerreas gallery but the door was locked. At length we took the car and went to Canastata, thence on foot to Mr. Yales (F's father in law) where F packed his good for California. we then repaired

Journal 1852
to (  ) and stayed till night. In the evening I attended prayer meeting.
Saturday 27th After breakfast Mr A and I sent to Kirkville on an errand. On our return, Mr A to save travel went across the lots and I kept the road. I called at friend () on my way and paid them a short visits. Afternoon I took my gun, and (in company with others) went a hunting but found no game. As night drew near I returned home. Thus passed the day.
Sunday 28th The mighty King of day arose with his usual splendor, and shone forth from a cloudless sky, and  cheering with his glittering rags, the face of nature. The aerial  songsters filled the air with their musical notes and the cattle joyfully roamed over the fields to greet the silver light of the new born day. A pleasanter day then this is seldom seen. In the forenoon I attended church. Afternoon I went to Mr. T's and stayed till night. I then returned home.
Monday 29th After breakfast I went to the Post Office and mailed two letters, thence to the grocery, thence to (  ) where I cracked some jokes (  ) I then went home, helped brother & set some fence posts, till noon. Afternoon

Journal 1852
Wednesday 24th
I spend the forenoon in casting balls and slugs for my fire-arms. Afternoon friend J () and I spent some time in shooting at a mark; my rifle got out of order; therefore we ceased firing. I then took my rifle to blacksmith shop for repairs, and I went home. My gun being repaired, friend J () went a hunting. On our way we called at Brother B's whom we invited to take my revolver and bear us company. Not finding game plenty, we turned our attention to firing at a mark; this exercise we continued till new night. The remainder of the day I spent at home.
Thursday 25th I spent the forenoon in chit-chat, casting slugs for my rifle () I stayed at home a portion of the afternoon. The remainder I spent at  ( )'s
Friday 26th After breakfast I took my rifle and went to (  ) where I spent the forenoon in conversation, shooting at a mark, singing (). Afternoon I returned home and friend A came with me. We then spent some time snowballing and then went

Journal 1852
Afternoon I went to the blacksmith shop and cast about three pounds of balls. I then returned, ate my supper, and went to Mr. T's and spent the evening. ()
Friday 2nd I scored timber for Brother J till one pm. I then took my rifle to N.M. and spent the remainder of the day shooting at a mark. In the evening I went to Mr T/s and I made a sack for my rifle; after which I returned home thus passed the day.
Saturday 3rd I spent the day in visiting the different parts of our vicinity, conversing upon different topics ()
Sunday 4th The sun rose with his usual splendor, and sent his cheering rays unobstructed to add life and beauty to the face of nature. I attended church and listened to two sermons by the Rev Mr Brown after which I went to Mr A's and stayed a short time then returned home. About half past four pm I went the Mr T's and stayed till half past eight. I then returned and retired.
Monday 5th It being the day in which I were to start for California I found it necessary to arise early, and prepare for the enterprise. Soon the hour arrived in which I was to start

Journal 1852
I took some paper and went Mr () where I made (for a special use) a paper collar. I then returned home and remained till sunset. Brother J (    ) T, and myself then went the village of North M. where we spent the evening in a very interesting manner. The exercises of the evening were (   ) meeting like Psuedo-(corrsimbial) FC of which Mr. L was the subject. The vegetable essentials were also present.
Tuesday 30th. The day was cloudy, windy and unpleasant. I scored timber for Broth J till about four pm. I then went to mr H's in search for horse-raddish to grate, and take on my journey to California. But I found none. Brother J and I then went to Mr D's where we found plenty. We then dug a quantity and brought it home, and spent the evening in grinding it on the grater.
Wednesday 31st I spent the forenoon at  (   ). Afternoon I visited Brother B and Mr (   ). The evening I spent at Mr T's
Thursday April 1st After breakfast I took my cans of horse raddish to Mr C's and soldered them shut. I then went home and Mr. A bore me company.

Journal 1852
Soon we were in rapid motion toward our place of destination. Many and variable were the thoughts that ran over my brain while the puffing and rattling locomotive was hurrying me from the land of my birth. We arrived at the state line, at 3 pm. We then exchanged cars, and proceeded on our journey, and arrived at Erie Penn at or near 5 pm. Our baggage was then conveyed to the steam boat Julius Molten where we purchased tickets for Cleaveland Ohio, We then went to the American Hotel and took supper, then returned to the boat and turned in for the night. The middle of the boat Julius Molten on the night of Apr 6th 1852 (     )
Wednesday 7th I arose from the table on which I slept and went on deck to take the fresh sea breeze ( ) at length breakfast was brought on and each grabbed a stody and seated himself by the table and unamiously began to fill his bread basket. After breakfast myself and several of my comrades went to the wharf and shot at a mark till near noon, when we returned our guns to the boat. The remainder of the day we spent in various ways, such as walking, talking, laughing

Journal 1852
Brother B, having business at Syracuse, consented to take me, and my luggage with him there. At quarter past ten, we reached the City. We then went to a daguer-rean Gallery, where I got myself put in a frame and handed it to him to carry to brother J. I then walked through the streets in different directions, till one o clock pm. I then got onboard the Express and soon was on my way to Buffalo. Through pleasant villages, and groves, and spacious fields, I was hurried by the power of steam till I reached the City of Buffalo' which was at half past nine pm; myself and company was then directed to a Hotel where we put up for the night.
Tuesday 6th I arose at 6 o clock and in company with a few of my comrades bound for C took a morning walk. While walking through the streets of Buffalo, we conversed on the different objects our eyes chanced to meet. Having finished our walk, we returned to the Hotel. At half past 9 we repaired to the Depot, purchased our tickets to the State line, and took our seats in the cars

fast approaching and we started on our return and arrived at the dock about dusk.
Saturday 10th According to previous arraingement our company left the steamer JS Morton before breakfast in the morning. I went in a grocery and bought my breakfast. I then took my rifle and shot several times a a loon, a duck, a mark () I then returned, and with the rest of my company put my baggage aboard of a canal boat bound for Beaver, At 3 pm our boat was in motion toward its destined port. All passed off smoothly till night when the chilly air drove all in the midships (for the cabin was very small. A rude little coal stove, constitued our fireplace. Our floor consisted of 600 bushels of barley. Our Indian blankets were our bed clothes. Thus we passed the night on a bed of barley. Peace and content will crown the heads of all who trust in their God and Creator.
Sunday 11th I spent the day in walking on the tow path, sitting in the midship of our boat, conversing, reading the Bible ()
Monday 12th The Sun unvailed by clouds shone with his usual splendor, during the entire day. After breakfast, myself and several of my comrades took our guns and went ahead of the boat, a distance of 6 or 7 miles to a place called the reservoir. I shot ducks

joking, forming ourselves into a jews harp band ()
Thursday 8th The King of day arose and rode unvailed through the sky all day. Our boat the (   ) is still ice bound. After breakfast friend Lewis () and I walked up town and returned near noon. Walk through the village between the hours of  (   )I then went on uncle sam's dock and saw some of my comrades shoot at a mark. Being tired of suck sport I went in a public building and soon found myself involved in a  peculiar philosophic argument about powder and balls. Leaving my visit there I returned to the boat and stayed till after tea. Friend Huggins and I then took another walk and returned about dusk. I spent the evening and night in cabin. ()
Friday 9th The weather fine. The captain ordered the fireman to fire up and all hands prepared for a (   ) for clean land. At 10 o clock the boat was in motion a cruise of two hours our boat was obliged to return on account of the ice. From that time till four pm. There myself and others of my comrades obtained a small boat and crafted the bay in search of ducks. We saw several, but shot none. Night was

beauties of its situation. The whole village is surrounded by some of the most beautiful hills and table lands my eyes ever beheld.
Thursday 15th Feeling rather unwell, I arose at an early hour; and went a short distance up town and purchased some crackers; a few of which I ate; not thinking it prudent to eat a hearty breakfast. I spent the forenoon in walking about ((town connersing)) At noon the steamer editor arrived and myself and comrads took our baggage and went aboard. Soon we were rapidly sailing down the Rio Ohio toward its junction. The scenery on both sides the river was delightfully romantic. We passed several small towns during the afternoon. The sun has sent and I must lay aside my pen " Protem"
Friday 16th All day long I was rapidly hurried down the Rio Ohio by the engines of the Packet Editor. We passed several towns our boat stopped at Pomroy to get coal for the engine. I an some of my comrads went (while the crew was loaning coal) and visited the coal mine (which was near the river) The passage leading to the mine (we were

But the ducks were shy and kept out of our reach. We then proceeded to Kearstown and waited the arrival of the boat, which was 10  o'clock. am I then went on board and remained more or less the rest of the day. The region of country over which we passed during the day was beautiful, the surface is undulating. he timber of various kinds and thrifty granite. 
Tuesday 13th The King of day rode in majestic splendor through the sky without a cloud to obstruct his gilttering rays. During the day we passed trhough the villages of Greenville Middlesex and New Castle ( ) and through as beautiful a region of country as my eyes ever beheld. () several of the celebrated Pensylvania coal miles.
Wednesday 14th The day was rainy and unpleasant. I arose at 4 and went on deck and remained till we arrived at Beaver Pa which was at 5 am. Myself and comrads there took our baggage to a hotel, where we made our home through the day. During the day, I and some of my comrads went through different parts of the village noticed its location, and remarked the

hurried down the river Ohio. the level lands of Indianna mark the limits of the river on the north west and that of Kentucky on the south east. Fields of thrifty growing grain and natures carpet of green;  noble farm houses with pertaining comfort, greet the eye of the passer by and fills his hear with admiration. When I contemplate the beauties of the works of nature and the perfect order in which natures god has placed all his works my heart is filled with wonder, love, and praise. Our boat during the day landed at new Albany Ind, and Portland Key
Monday 19th We were still hurried down the Ohio by the power of our puffing engine. We at several small ports, during the day, one of which was nearly overflowed by the river. It was truly a hard looking place. I wondered that human beings could be content to dwell in such and unpleasant and health destroying place. The region through which we passed today is low land apparently marshy and decidedly the most miserable and forsaken looking region I ever saw we passed several houses during the day that were built on stilts to keep them above the high water mark

told by the miners) was one mile and a quarter in length from its entrance at the mountain side. The picturesque appearance of the river and and its banks cannot but fill the mind of the beholder with admiration. Virginia, with her towering hills, maple groves, and table lands and fields of thrifty growing wheat, touches the river on the east, while the new, well cultivated hardy and thrifty growing Ohio touches on the west. Order, prosperity, and comfort, seems to be marked on the features of every thing the eye can reach.
Saturday 17th We rode gayly down the Rio Ohio at eleven am our boat landed at Cincinatti, and remained till 3 pm during that time friends L & S and I took a walk through a portion of the city to learn something of its location. It is a noble city situated on the north east side of the river, It is teeming with almost every species of business that city life and customs demand. The land on each side of the river is extremely beautiful. Well cultivated farms and noble groves of timber reach from the river back as far as the eye can reach.
Sunday 18th Still, by the mighty power of steam (regardless of the sabbath) we are

Thursday 22nd Our boat, during the night, reached the end of her journey (St Louis) When we arose in the  morning we found her still and among the multitude of steam cars that are laying in the port of the noble city (St Louis). During the day we shipped our wagons and baggage on board the Steamer Yuba bound for St Josephs. I purchased (during the day) a canteen, belt () St L is a noble city situated on the west bank of the Missippi about 14 miles south of the mouth of the Missouri, her streets are comparatively narrow, but generally regular and clean. She is also teeming with the active business of city life.
Friday 23rd Our boat (the Yuba) not being sufficiently loaded, did not leave port during the day. We were consequently compelled to spend the day in St Louis. I spend the day similar to that of yesterday. Night came, and friend Loucks and I took up our lodging on the hurricane deck, having concluded to take deck passage to Independence.
Saturday 24th In company with some of my conrads (quite early in the morning) I took a walk during which we visited the shot tower of St L. About nine am our boat left port and shaped her course

of the Rio Ohio. And some were entirely surrounded by the waters of that raging river.
Tuesday 20th About nine am our boat landed at Cairo (Situated at the junction of the Ohio and Mississippi rivers) and let off passengers and took on wood for her engine. She then headed up the M but in consequance of the current, and a strong head wind she made slow progress. We also landed at Cape Girardeau in Missouri. The borders of Illinois on the east side of the river which we passed today are low and apparently mossy. That of Missouri for several miles is undulating and rocky. In many places may be seen high and firmly seated cliffs, as if erected by nature to break the winds and storms of the east and keep the flowing Mississippi from trespassing upon the land that were not her own.
Wednesday 21st Still, against wind and tide, we were driven up the M by the ((Oditar's)) engine, the region brought to view by this days travel on the east of the river is low & level. That on the west is various such as high hills and bluffs deep vallies and long levels () During the day we passes Uncle Sam's Military post, called at his quarantine grounds ()

Tuesday 27th About one o clock  a.m. our boat landed at Glassgow (Missouri() and having a quantity of lumber and shingles aboard consigned to that port, she remained till that portion of her cargo was unshipped; which took till nine a.m. we then proceeded on our journey up the river, touching at several places to get wood for our engine. At six p.m. we landed at Brunswick to unship some salt and iron. The country on each side of the river is various: Some parts undulating others low and level. The settlements along the river are few and far between. The weather to day has been fine.
Wednesday 28th Our boat made poor progress. The river being very shallow. About six o'clock came to a shallow spot in the river which it took her three hours to pass. From that time till three p.m., she ran on several sand bars, but (  ) backed off, and went on her way. At three p.m. She ran aground, and, remained (   ), by that time her crew got her loose, and directed her ashore, where she was tied up for the night. The day was fine, and comparatively warm. We saw during the day a few good looking farms and one large pararie.
Thursday 29th Early in the morning our boat fired up and started for anew on her journey. Against wind and current she ran till

up the river. About eleven am she reached the mouth of the Missouri which our boat entered and was hurried on her course. Curing the day she was once in a sand bar, once on shore, and once on a snag. The day was mostly rainy and unpleasant. The land on each side of the river is generally lower and thinly settled.
Sunday 25th Still, we were hurried up the Rio Missouri. our boat stopped once during the day. The country on each side of the river consisted of a variety of hills, plains, and ravines. I spent the day  mostly in reading and meditation.
Monday 26th The day was cloudy, windy, cold & unpleasant. We were driven on our course against wind and current by the mighty engine of the Yuba. We passed several towns during the day; the first of which was Jefferson City (the capital Missouri) On each side of the river, we occassionally saw high cliffs of rocks, pleasant farm house and well cultivated farms. Also low marshy lands and dense forests. The Missouri river is generally wide shallow; containing many snags, sandbars. Its waters are extremely muddy and its current strong and rapid.

May
Saturday May 1st According to previous arrangement we began in the morning to prepare for a move to Pleasant Hill. About 11 a.m. (the waggons being rigged) myself, and five others or our company went to the farm yard of a wealthy farmer (a distance of 1/2 or 3/4 of a mile) after our mules. After laboring about 2 hours we caught them and returned. The mules were then harnessed and hitched to the waggons. All things being ready we started for Pleasant Hill (a distance of 20 miles) where we arrived about seven p.m. The region through which we passed was mostly perarie which is decidedly the most beautiful of any land I ever saw. On our arrival we were conducted to a log house standing in a lot about 1/4 of a mile from the road, where we were to make our home till we started over the plains. The house being destitute of any kind of furniture, we found it necessary to use our blankest and valiese in place of furniture. Being thus provided for we turned in for the night having enjoyed a pleasant, though windy day.
Sunday 2nd In the forenoon I rode a mule to church, a distance of two miles. The remainder of the day I spent at the house of Mr Fleming (where myself and comrads make our home, about dark I went to the old long house and turned in for the night.

near nine o'clock p.m. when she landed us and our baggage at Wayne city (Misssouri) Six of our company then went to  independence and the remainder stayed through the night. Our beds were rude mattrasses lain upon the floor of a rude looking Inn. The price of lodging 25
Friday 30th I arose from the pallet o which I had slept during the night, and went to the wharf where I found Captain Gale, and two others of the company putting together the waggons, and preparing to transport (     ) our baggage to Independence. At 11 o'clock, our wagons being hitched on, we started for Independence. Over hills, and vallies, amid driving winds, and clouds of dust, we trudged along till we reached Independence (a distance of 5 miles) Thence we were conducted to the house of Mr Smart (one mile south) where we spent the rest of the day in cleaning our harness getting out stuff for waggon boxes () Independence and its immediate vacinity is as beautiful, and pleasant a spot as I ever saw. The land is undulating, the soil extremely fertile, the timber chiefly oak and basswood. Mr Smart is a wealthy slave-holder owning 2,000 acres of land and slaves to till it. The day was pleasant.

manner of starting (  ) after which some of our boys sand several songs. 
Saturday 8th The forenoon was pleasant; the afternoon mostly rainy. We spent the forenoon in selecting our teams and breaking them, loading our waggons ( ) preparatory to a start for Independence. After dinner we took leave of our friend John F harnessed our mules, and started. Our mules being comparatively wild and ungovernable we had some trouble in getting them across the ditches and sloughs we found on our way. Night overtook us before we reached Mr. (Smearts) the place where we were to put up for the night and we consequently had to finish our journey in the dark. The sky was cloudy and the darkness so dense that we could not see our lead mules 1/2 of the time. While in the dark we ran afowl of a stump and had some difficulty in releasing ourselves from it. with that exception we had good luck; all things considered we arrived at the destined spot at () p.m.
Sunday 9th I spent the day at Mr Smearts my thought and feelings during the day may better be imagined than described. I found it difficult to confine my thought to one subject more than a few minutes at a time.

May
Monday 3rd I arose at an early hour fixed my pants, and went to breakfast. after breakfast friend ((Malhewson)) and I mounted astrid a couple of mules and went to Pleasant Hill, and was vaccinated; we then returned, and I spent the remainder of the forenoon hemming tent cloth. The afternoon myself and comrads spent in branding mules, playing ball ( ) The day was pleasant.
Tuesday 4th I spent the day on the farm of John Fleming. Nothing of importance transpired with my observation during the day. Having exercised freely yesterday I did not feel very lively and consequently labored little. During the day I wrote a letter for Friend Adams. 
Wednesday 5th I spent the day sewing tent cloth, helping catch mules, playing ball () The day was pleasant.
Thursday 6th I rode to town once during the day; the remainder I spend in sewing waggon covers shooting at a mark
Friday 7th We spent the day in finishing our waggons and preparing to start for Ind the next day. in the evening our company held a council in the door yard of J Fleming, concerning the division of the teams the

we spent in conversations attending to our teams () About ( ) p.m. a horse came galloping in the camp with so much fury as to frighten our mules. Many of them drew their pickets and ran unceremoniously about the prairie. Our  men immediately rallied, and after working and searching about two hours in the rain and dark they succeeded in repicketing the frightened jacks. We then retired to our tents. During the day we passed the graves of two luckless and a (     ) of tracking Spaniards (    )
Thursday 13th About 1/2 past 6 we struck our tents, harnessed our teams and again started on our journey. Hour after hour we drove along over the undulating prairie part of the time entirely out of sight of the least shrub or tree till 7 P.M. when we pitched our tents () thus passed the day.
Friday 14th Early in the morning some of our mules stampeded and three of our boys mounted their riding steeds and followed them. After a chase of 4 or 5 miles they overhauled them and brought them back. We then struck our tents and again started on our journey. About 10 a.m. we forded a small stream whose banks were so steep and miry that we had to fasten a rope to the (  ) and all hands take hold and help our teams. Having  (   ) this a distance of 5 miles we came to the Wancarucia Creek which we were obliged to ford. there being more than 100 waggons in the

Monday 10th We spend the forenoon in fixing our harness and waggons for the great enterprise before us. Afternoon we drove to the town and got our provisions for the journey. On our return my ((Muff)) pitched their tent, put their harness and baggage in it to protect them from the rain. Friend ((Meatherou)) and I then went up stairs in the house and stayed till near night. The remainder of the day we spent in a (fallnell)) sort of way. The afternoon was rainy and unpleasant.
Tuesday 11th In the forenoon we harnessed our teams and made a few other preparations for our journey. At half past 2 p.m. we started over the plains. Over hill & dale, through the most beautiful region I ever saw, we trudged along, a distance of  or 10 miles, and camped for the night. Each (  ) with rope and (  ) picket fastened their mules for the night. This being done, we cooked our supper, and rudely sat around a few burning fagots and ate our first supper on the plains. After supper we turned in for the night.
Wednesday 12th We arose early and fed our mules. We then attended to breakfast, after which we harnessed our teams and again started on our journey. The day being rainy we camped at 3 p.m. The rest of the day

times and in most directions. We have encountered strong and and changable winds for the hills are not very high, and timber is seldom seen. We have already been several times entirely out of sight of either tree or shrub. The extensive prairies of the Indian territory (in which we now are, and have been for 3 1/2 days) cannot but fill the mind of the beholder with admiration. The surface is generally undulating; and covered with natures rich carpet of green. Were it not for the scarcety of timber and water privaliges, they might be classed among the most delightful and fertile regions the world could produce. At all times of day, may be seen large herds of cattle, moving like a vast cloud toward that state where excitement rages. The marks of old camp fires and the many places where the grass is closely croped plainly show the effect of Gold on the human mind.
About noon we camped, ate our dinners or raw hams & crackers. After an hour 's nooning we packed, crack and sack and soon was under motion. We had not went more than 4 miles when every spoke in my hind wheel of waggon #3 broke (waggons No 3 we purchased at Inc) About 20 minutes after the breakdown the rain and hail began to decend in perfet torrents. wind and almost purpetual lighting and the roaring rolling artilery of the air added gloom t our condition. The fury storm continued til

bank (which was very steep and muddy) we found our turn would not come in that place that day. We consequently left the place and went 6 miles farther up the creek where the water was not so deep and the number of waggons less. When we reached the place we found the way clear. We then overhauled our teams and put 5 of our best teams together and began one of the most pokerish and perilous tasks that I ever was engaged in. The bank was very high and steep (it being about 70 feet from the top to the water which was so deep that we had to raise our waggon boxes to keep them out of the water) we tied long ropes the the hind axels and all hands with might and ( main? ) took hold and helped the teams hold the loads and ease them (one at a time) down the fearful steep. It was with extreme difficulty that our mules assended the opposite bank; which was nearly as steep and difficult as the others. Dark overtook us before our task was done. Having reached the opposite shore we pitched our tent, cooked our suppers and retired. Thus passed a day of singular adventures.
Saturday 14th At 8 a.m. we struck our tents and again pulled for the land of Aurusm. During the forenoon we passed several ox trains bound for C; We are now in a region where numerous trains of California waggons may be seen at all

Friend ((Meatthewson)) and guarded the mules till midnight. While on guard we heard in a distant ravine, the howling of wolves, the chatter or nocturnal birds ()
Tuesday 15th At 1/2 past 6 a.m. we strick our tents and renewed our journey. The day being cool our mules traveled faster than usual. I found it difficult to keep pace with them without an occasional quick step. My boots became burdensome and I took them off and traveled in my stocking feet. At 1 p.m. we arrived at the Caw River where we remained till 5 p.m. waiting for our turn to ferry across. We saw a large number of waggons on the river ferrying and waiting to ferry. We also saw several Indians pass and (   ) who appeared to notice our mules closely. They belong to the Caw Chifeways  once Polawatanie tribes. Having crossed the river we traveled 1 1/2 mile and camped for the night. During the night the surrounding woods rang with the howling of wolves. The day was pleasant, though rather cold.
Wednesday 18th We struck our tents at 1/2 past 6 a.m. and traveled at a ((        )) pace. We passed several trains in the forenoon and some of

5 p.m. when it partially subsided; Our Captain then appointed 2 men to watch the broken waggon and the remainder of the company with the unbroken waggons went 3 1/2  miles back and encamped. After picketing our jacks we retired to our waggons soaking wet. The ground was so wet and muddy that we could not pitch our tents; We consequently were obliged to spend the night in our waggon. Tus wet and cold I spent a night the most disagreeable of any in my life.
Sunday 16th This was our first Sabbath in the Indian Territory. The day was cold and cloudy. I arose from the uncomfortable position in which I had lain through the night and went to the fire (which some of my cconrads had built) and dried my clothes after which I felt comparatively comfortable. I spent a portion of the day in the waggon writing in my journal, talking sitting around the fire () O how few and ((seant)) are the christian privaliges on  Prairies of the western world.
Monday 17th We spent the forenoon cutting our waggon boxes shorter and mending the broken wheels. At 1/2 past 1 p.m. During the afternoon we passed a travelers grave, two Indians, an ox () We are now in a region where large traveling trains may be seen all times of day. About 7 p.m. we are camped. The day was fine. The night cold and clear.

Friday 21st Early in the morning it began to rain and continued till (( )) AM. We then harnessed our teams, struck our tents & proceeded on our journey. Over hills, and through vallies we trudged along till 1/2 past 4 PM when we (having traveled about 12 miles) camped on the bank of a beautiful little stream of water, where there was plenty of wood and peace of comfort was marked on the features of every thing the eye could behold. O! there is something in the appearance of the wild Prairies of the Indian Territory that seem fraught with interest. Some thing that tends to lead the human mind from created object up to the Creator.
We are now in the Potawatamy tribe. Since Tuesday of this week we have passed 136 emigrant waggons
Saturday 22nd At 7 AM we struck our tents and renewed our journey. We had gone but a short distance from camp when one of our mules too a fit of the dreadful ((sees)) and rared and kicked till she broke her whiffle tree. Her conduct was such that it took 2 men to hold her. We were detained about 2 hours when all things was again ready and we rolled on to a creek whose waters were so deep that we were obliged to raise our waggon boxes to keep them

the Caw Indians. Our route today was more hilly than any before for we traveled over hills and through vallies all day. At noon we halted & let our mules graze. About 3 p.m. one of our teams took fright and ran a distance of 10 or 50 rods. During the fracus one of the mules fells, and the fore end of the waggon ran over her Mr Lewis was driving at that time. His foot hold gave way and he fell on the ((meafr) between the wheel span but was not hurt. At 7 p.m. we camped on a beautiful hillside at the foot of which ran a crystal stream where stood a handsome grove of trees.
Thursday 20th At 6 a.m. we struck our tents & again moved onward. Nothing of note transpired during the day. But all moved off pleasantly. We say 3 wolves and the grave of an unlucky traveler during the day. At (()) p.m. we camped by the road side where we used weeks for fervel & the feed was very poor. Here is the place to try men's dispositions; for fatigue,  inconvenience , and exposure are here combined.

The day is calmly ending
The evening spreads her vail
With hearts and voiced blended
This peacful hour we hail"
Monday 24th At 7 AM we struck our tents and again renewed our march. A 9 we arrived at the big blue; which we forded without difficulty. Near its banks we saw one grave, and an encampment nearly destitute of teams the Indians having stampeded and stolen them. Having forded the blue we traveled 9 miles & turned out for noon. A 1 PM we retackled our jacks and went on. During the afternoon we padded the new made grave of J Skidmore and an encampment of emigrates from St Joseph bound for C in which there had 11 of their conrads died, and the twelfth was very  near his end. The disease was said to be Cholera. During the day we passed a large number of Emigrant waggons, one of which was abandoned by its owners. At half past 6 PM in an beautiful piece of Prairie called the cotton wood branch feed and water was plenty. We are now in Pawnee Tribe.
Tuesday 25th We struck our tents at 7 AM We passed the little sandy at 11 AM At noon we halted for our mules to graze and to eat our dinner. At 1/2 past 12

above water. Its banks were so steep that had to fasten ropes to our waggons, and ((  )) them around a stump to ease them down to the creek. Near the creek we saw the ruins of a covered buggy and two new made graves. Having crossed the creek, we traveled about 3 miles and camped in a beautiful place covered with natures carpet of green and where wood, water, and feed was plenty. Friend Matthewson and I was appointed to guard the mules the later part of the night.
Sunday 23rd This being the lords day, we did not roll out of camp: but spent the day till 6 PM in reading, conversation () At 6 PM our Captain delivered an exhortation to us which was comprehensive, beneficial, and spiritual. While he was speaking, my heart glowed with thankfulness to the great author of the Universe for his merciful kindness, and protecting care which had been over us thus far on our journey. And I felt an increased determination to make the religion of Jesus the chief business of my life and to regard the things pretaining to earth as secondary. Surely there is a peace in believing in the Lord Jesus which the earth cannot afford.

condition very dangerous, he ordered the train not to stop. We accordingly at the usual hour (1 o'clock) harnessed our jacks and rolled on. Having gone a distance of 3 miles, and while passing a difficult spot in the rod the nigh fore wheel of one of our waggons broke. Being thus disabled we were obliged to stop and repair. A traveler hapening along at that time told us that he had passed a wheel about 4 miles back which he thought would answer our purpose. Three of our boys then went in pursuit of the wheel, others in pursuit of a suitable place too encamp while others stayed with the broken waggon. While standing there two ladies dressed in the Bloomer Costume came along each in possession of a riding beast. They were so uncommonly talkative that they soon drew the attention all who were standing near. One of them bounded astride of her prancing steed, placed her feet in the sturrups, and with and air of supremacy drew the reigns rode a few rods, and waited for her associate to follow her example. Her associate feeling the effect of nature modesty concluded she would wait till she reached the other side of the hill.Well thought I these are the women for the overland route to California. Such are the women for me. Having found a suitable place to camp 1/2 mile distant, we went

it began to rain and continued more or less till 1/2 past 4 p.m. Night drew near and we camped on a side hill where the feed was not very food, wood was scarce & water poor. During the day we passed 3 graves; one of which was new. On a board at the head of the new grave was written the important sentence "Prepare to meet thy God Oh ((     ))
Wednesday 26th We struck our tents 7 a.m. & again rolled on. At 9 we crossed the big sandy. At noon we halted and let our animals graze. At 1 .m. we again caught our jacks and moved onward. The Prairie over which we passed this afternoon was generally more level that that we passed before. At 1/2 past 5 p.m. we camped on the bank of Ale Creek. Wood was plenty, and water tolerable. During the day we saw four graves one of which was made this morning. On a stake at the head of one was written "Name unknown"
Thursday 27th At 6 a.m. we struck our tents and renewed our march. All things moved on pleasantly and in good time. At 11 we reached the little blue and traveled along its banks about 1 mile and halted to take in wood and water & let our animals graze. About 11 our Captain was attached with the Cholera; but not considering himself

weather was excessive hot and the water poor. Sickness and death seemed to stare us in the face. Several persons died in some of the camps joining ours but the King of terrors did not visit us.
Sunday 30th The weather still excessive hot & sickness dwells in our camp. Our Captain is still gaining. This morning I felt that the medicine and care administered by our faithful boys (by the direction of Providence) had reached my case, and I began slowly to mend. This Lord's day was a serious day to us, for we were here exposed to burning heat and raging thirst and at a great distance from good water.
Monday 31st Our Captain has so far recovered that he is again able to lead the train. This morning I found myself a little better. In view of our being in a very sickly place, and surrounded by the sick and dying, it was considered expedient to roll out of camp. A bed was acordingly fixed in the waggon for me, on which I placed myself, and as soon as the teams were harnessed, we rolled on. We rolled on, over the plains till 5 p.m. when my condition made it necessary to encamp. Our encampment was on the table lands of the little blue. The remainder of the day and most of the night I endured the

there with the unbroken waggons, and pitched our tents (having left a guard with the broken one) The boys in pursuit of the above wheel returned with it about dusk. Our afflicted Captain still grew worse till about  Midnight, the cause seemed to be measurably removed. This passed a beautiful, though partially unfortunate day with us. During the day we passed twelve graves.
Friday 28th Our Captain being sick, we did not roll out of camp during the day. In the forenoon, myself and two others of my comrads went to the river (the little blue) where we bathed and washed some of our clothes. We returned to camp about noon. About 2 p.m. I was taken with purging, faintness, and sickness of the stomach. Finding myself sick, I retired to my tent, took a portion of medicine and waited its effect. Our Captain during the day grew better, his disease having reached its highest point and  turned in his favor.
Saturday 29th We still remain in camp on account of sickness. Several of our company felt the symptoms of cholera. Our Captain will gained, and I grew worse. Our faithful boys gave me the best of care through the day, but still I grew no better. The

had fatigued me very much still my symptoms were a little better. Today we passed 12 graves.
Wednesday June 2nd At 6 a.m. we struck our tents and shaped our course for Fort Kearney a distance of 36 miles situated on the Platte river (The Prairie over which we passed to day is level) we reached the fort at 6 p.m. We here found good water, the first we had seen for several days. Each mess filled their keg  and canteen with the precious element. We were all much revived at ounce more seeing what appeared like civilization. Uncle Sam had stationed here men and field pieces for the protection of the civiliized and peaceful. Here stood a noble dwelling in which the comforts of life appeared to dwell. There is also a store near the Fort in which some of our boys made some purchases. Having finished our business at the Fort, we went about 1 1/2 miles & camped near the shore of the Rio Platte. During the night we encountered a terrible storm of wind and rain. The wind blew so hard that our tents could not stand. Finding it impossible to keep our tent pinned to the ground, two of our boys stood over me and held the tent to screen me from the storm for my

most excruciating pain in my bowels and stomach that I ever had experienced. To day we passed eighteen graves.
Tuesday June 1st This morning being somewhat better I again felt able to ride. At 6 1/2 a.m. we again rolled out. At 10 a.m. we passed a train some of whose members were in the act of burying one of their number who had died with the cholera. At 10 1/2 our Captain rode to a camp a few rods from the road in which he found one person dying and two others were dangerously ill. at 11, we reached the point from which we were to leave the little blue. We here halted to let our animals graze. A few rods ahead of us stood two waggons whose apprearance and location bore the marks of distress. Our Captain and two others rode up to them They there found a woman with the cholera apparently in the agonies of death. Captain immediately dismounted and ordered those that were with him to follow. They then united their efforts to relive the unhappy suffered. By their activity and the aid of medicine. 2 p.m. they had succeeded in relieving the sufferrer; We then moved on till 6, when we camped for the night. The ride through the day

special transpired during the day except some of our boys went over the Bluffs in pursuit of game. They took no game, but on their return they found a mule, saddle, and bridle. At 6 p.m. we again camped on the P. Here we found a good spring of water and plenty of wood. Today we passed 4 graves.
Sunday 6th This being the Lords day we did not roll out of camp but spent most of the day in reading conversation ( ) The messes united and cooked a general supper, which was spread on the ground, and all hands with the Captain at the head, seated themselves around this rude table, and enjoyed what we called a union feast. Our meal consisted of a potpie made of antelope, biscuit fried cakes, tea, coffee, cheese ( ) At 5 p.m. we held a religious meeting, in which our Captain addressed us in a very appropriate and profitable manner. I felt much benefited by his remarks, and felt to tank God that our leader was a man who lived and walked in the fear of the Lord.
Monday 7th One of our men being sick, we did not roll out of camp till 7 1/4  o clock. We gradually rolled along the low shore of the Platte till noon; we then halted, ate our dinners and let our

condition was such that it would have been exceedingly dangerous for me to get wet. This was indeed a horrible night. We passed 12 graves during the day.
Thursday 3rd Being wet, and cold, we did not stop for breakfast but harnessed our teams and traveled about 5 miles when we stopped and cooked & ate our breakfast. This being done we again proceeded on our journey. About 3 p.m. we reached the ford of the Platte, Captain and Mr T examined the ford and found it  under present circumstances impassible. We then started for the south fork, a distance of (9)1 miles. About dusk we camped on the level bank of the Rio Platte. Today we passed 5 graves.
Friday 4th At 6 a.m. we again rolled out of camp. The road was good and level. At noon we halted by the roadside, ate our dinners & let our animals graze. At the usual hour we harnessed and rolled on. During the afternoon we saw several buffaloes & antelope at a distance, but did not give them chase. At 6 1/2 we again camped on the shore of the Platte. Water was plenty and wood scarce. Today we padded 4 graves.
Saturday 5th At 6 we rolled out of camp toward our destined place. Nothing

boys killed an Antelope, and saw several Buffaloes.
Thursday 10th Having our provisions to repack we did not roll out of camp till 8 o'clock. We traveled a NW course till we reached Ash hollows (a distance of 16 miles from the Platte) We here had to descent 100 ft in going about 10 rods; this brought us in the hollow. This valley is from 30 to 50 rods wide and 2 miles long. On one side the ledge of Granite is about 200 feet high, the other side was variable. In this valley we found three kinds of wild roses, wild onions, choke cherries, black cherries, 1 wild currant, grapes, ash, and cotton wood trees. There is also a good spring of water in this valley. At the mouth of this valley we struck the north fork of the Platte where we had halted and let our mules graze. We remained here till 5 p.m. We then rolled on a distance of 5 miles and encamped for the night Today we passed nine graves.
Friday 11th At 1/2 past 6 we rolled out of camp. At noon we halted 2 hours a little off from the road, where we found a good spring of water and feed tolerable. At 2 p.m. we again traveled on till 7

animals graze. At 1 1/2 p.m. we again rolled on during the afternoon we saw an antelope, and several wolves. Having found good feed and a good camping place about 1 mile from the river at 5 p.m. we camped. we here for the first time cooked our suppers with buffalo chips. Today we passed 12 graves.
Tuesday 8th We struck our tents at 1/2 before 6, at 10 a.m. we reached the south fork of the Platte, up which we traveled till 5 1/2 p.m. when we camped on its south bank. The feed good & water tolerable, our fuel was Buffalo chips. Some of our boys saw several Buffaloes & Antelope. Today we padded 3 graves.
Wednesday 9th At 6 a.m. we struck our tents and rolled on till noon, when we halted for dinner and to let our animals graze. At 2 p.m. we again rolled on & at 4 p.m. we reached the ford of the south fork; the river was so high that we found it necessary to raise our provisions to the top of our waggon boxes to keep it from the water. This we done by means of poles and sticks Having passed the ford, we traveled about 100 rods up the river and encamped for the night. Today our

passed Chimney Rock. This rock is about 300 feet high, the base is 150 feet high, and was about 6 acres of land and slopes from the top to the ground. The top of the base is about 100 feet in diameter. From the top of the base, a rock 20 feet square runs up 150 feet farther. This last rock has the appearance of the chimney of some large factors. This rock can be seen at a distance of 40 miles. It stands 3 miles from the road. On it is engraved the names of thousands of people. The next thing that drew our attention was a number high rocks, standing close together. They appeared at a distance, like a large city. They area about as high as Chimney rock. Our camp was about 1 1/2 miles North of these rocks. After dinner we spent the remainder of the in conversation ( ) Today we passed two graves.
Monday 14th At 5 a.m. we struck our tents and rolled on. We had traveled about 2 miles when we can to a blacksmith shop made by sticking up 4 poles and by laying some of the same on the top and plastering them over with clay. The house was made by sticking poles in the ground in the form of a hay stack, and covered with dried skins. this constituted

6 o'clock when we camped about 50 rods from the river, having traveled 24 miles. The road today was sandy; the sand being from 4 to 5 inches. today we passed 14 graves.
Saturday 12th we struck our tents at 6 & rolled  on. We halted at noon as usual when we again found a good spring of water. At 2 p.m. we again started (the road was t very good) Soon after we started we passed Castle Bluff. This Bluff can be seen 25 miles distant. It resembles a court house or church. It stands about 5 miles from the road () We kept moving till 6 p.m. when a heavy shower came up and our mules refused to go. We then turned their backs to the storms and waited till it was over. We then drove a few rods and camped by the road side. Today we passed 10 graves, one of which the bones lay on the top of the ground; having been dug out by some wild animal.
Sunday 14th There being no wood nor Buffalo chips for fuel, and feed being poor, we were obliged to move up the river 12 miles, where we found a few Buffalo chips. We then camped. Soon after we started we

Here we found a trading post on each side of the river, and an Indian settlement a little off from the road. While our teams were grazing at noon, Nearly all of our company wrote home. After dinner we drove to the Fort (a distance of one mile) where we staid till 5 p.m. The houses here are mostly built of sods, the walls are about 2 feet thick 7 18 feet high. The roof projects about 3 feet. Here the Government has a Military post with 2 or 3 pieces of cannon. There is also a store, bakery, blacksmith shop. At 5 p.m. we rolled on. 2 miles distant passed a trading post & 2 miles farther we camped in a valley near the river. Feed has poor but wood plenty. To day we passed 5 graves.
Thursday 17th Dr Smith being very sick, we concluded to remain in camp during the day. Several Indians passed and repassed our camp during the day.
Friday 18th Dr Smith being no better & feed very poor we were obliged to leave him and his mess and travel a distance of 16 miles to bitter coton wood creek, during the day we passed an Indian Settlement and a trading post where we traded one of our horses for a mule. We then traveled on. Our road lay along by the side of a bluff from 100 to 200

the settlement . Here the road turned and led over the Bluffs. Having traveled 10 miles farther we came to Scots Bluff (so called from a man by that name having been killed there some years ago. This can also be seen at a great distance. These Bluffs have very much the appearance of a City or fortification. ( ) One mile farther on we camped for noon. At 2 p.m. we again rolled on. Here the road leaves the river and passes over the Prairie. We rolled on till the road again struck the river. We here found a good camping place and camped at 1/2 past 5. Today we met two returning Californians, and passed 4 graves.
Tuesday 15th At 1/2 past 6 we again moved on. At noon we halted as usual. At 7 p.m. we camped not far from the river & near a trading post & a camp of Indians. As we came in sight the were about preparing for a horse race which we had the pleasure of seeing. To day we met another California Company, and passed 8 graves.
Wednesday 16 th At 7 we struck our tents 2 miles from camp we say a Grocery, 3 1/2 miles from this we cross the ( tole?   ) bridge over the Larimie river.

ed the Labontee river. We here camped for noon. Here we found a trading post & a small Indian Village. These Indians were richly ornamented; One of them had a Medal that had been present to him by Martin Van Buren. About 40 rods from camp was the grave of L Tate who was hung (on a cotton wood tree) for the murder of (ABiller) We saw the tree he was hung on, and a piece of he rope that held him. Having ate our dinner we rolled on a distance of 12 miles, when we camped. Feed was very poor and wood scarce.
Wednesday 23rd At 4 a.m. we rolled out of camp. At 10 we stoped and cooked our breakfast. we then moved on. At 7 p.m. we camped on the shore of Deer creek. Today we passed 7 graves
Thursday 24th At 7 a.m. we rolled on. Having traveled 4 miles we came to the North fork of the Platte. We traveled along its banks & when it having began to rain we camped for the rest of the day. We passed one grave.
Friday 25th At 6 we struck our tent & traveled along the banks of the fork. At 6 p.m. we camped on the

feet high. After traveling a mile or 2 we began to asscend the Rocky mountains. Having traveled 16 miles we camped 2 miles up the bitter cotton wood, where we found quack and wild Barley for our teams & plenty of wood. To day we passed 4 graves.
Saturday 19th we remained in Camp during the day. At 1/2 past 10 Mr Gale and one other went back after the Dr and his mess. To day some of our boys went a hunting. They saw several Antelope & Mountain Sheep but shot none.
Sunday 20th We still remain in camp. At 12 o'clock our Captain came with the mess we left (The Dr was some better) The remainder of the day we spent in conversation ()
Monday 21th Having filled our water keg we again rolled on. During the forenoon we crossed the creek 5 times. We then left it and traveled a NW course till noon. We then halted & let our animals graze as usual. At 2 p.m. we moved on till 5 p.m. when having found a good camping place we camped. To day we passed 4 graves.
Tuesday 22nd The fore part of the day our road was very uneven. At 1 p.m. we reach-

Independence Rock, we forded the Sweet water. 2 miles from the ford we passed the Devils gate which is 60 feet wide & 400 feet high. Here the water runs through a narrow passage in the Mountain. The road here is sandy which made heavy wheeling. at 12 we stoped for moon on the shore of the sweet water. At 2 p.m. we rolled on along the banks of the river till 5 p.m. when we camped near the river. Our fuel was oiled sage. We passed 7 graves. The days are warm, the nights cold, the roads sandy.
Tuesday 29th At 5 a.m. we struck our tents and renewed our journey. Having traveled 8 miles we left the Sweet water 6 miles farther on we struck it at the ford. Here is runs so near that mountain that there is hardly room for a road. Having passed the ford and traveled 1/2 mile, we stoped for noon, where we found very good feed. After a space of 2 hours we again moved on. Soon after we forded the sweet water, twice. We were here obliged to raise our waggon boxes 8 inches to keep  our provisions out of the water. at 5 p.m. we camped on the bank of the river where there was plenty of wild sage. This sage is scented somewhat like garden sage its stalk

bank of the river. Today we padded 2 graves.
Saturday 26th In the morning we harnessed our jacks and rolled a distance of 2 miles to the ferry. We had to wait 3 hours before our turn came, there being several trains ahead of us. we here found some Indian wigwams and a small trading post. we here say a returning California Co of 28 men & 70 mules, who spake unfavorable of California. Having reached the opposite shore we moved on till 3 p.m. when we stoped and let our jacks graze. after which we rolled on till dusk; when we were obliged to camp without wood or water & feed was very poor. We passed 2 graves
Sunday 27th At  4 a.m. we tacked our jack and rolled on till 7 a.m. when we stoped and cooked our breakfast. At 11 a.m. we moved on. At 5 p.m. we struck the Sweet water, where we camped 1 mile from Independence rock. This is a solitary rock from 120 to 150 feet high and 125 rods long. It has inscribed on it the names of thousand of travelers. To day we passed 6 graves.
Monday 28th At 6 a.m. we struck our tents and rolled on. One mile beyond

whose banks are steep and difficult of assent & descent. Soon after we came to a creek on whose bank in a ravine we saw a pile of snow 10 feet deep. 6 miles farther on we found grass one mile from the road. here we stoped for noon. Soon after we stoped it began to hail and rain, and continued more or less the rest of the day. We consequently remained in camp the rest of the day. It has been so cold to day that an over coat and mittens were desirable. To day we passed 4 graves.

answers very well for fuel. Today we passed 8 graves. We are now in the Rocky Mountains ipso facto. Huge piles of Rocks my be seen on every hand that are perfectly naked and barren. Some of the peaks run to a great hight, and their summit are covered with snow.
Wednesday 30th At 6 a.m. we struck & moved on. We here left the sweet water and traveled over the bluffs a distance of 15 miles when we again reached the same. We have found grass and stoped to graze our animals. After the space of 2 hours we moved some after we started we forded the sweet water 4 times. We then traveled 12 miles along its banks, when we turned to the east and traveled 5 miles and camped about 200 rods from the road in a ravine, where we found plenty of wood 2 good springs and tolerable feed for our mules. During the day we passed a  Salaratus mine and 6 graves. The snow caped mountains have been in sight all day.
Thursday July 1st At 6 a.m. we talked our long eared horses and trudged along. We crossed several little streams,

place was beautiful and romantic. The swift flowing river was on one side and high steep bluffs on the other/. On the shore of the river grows trees and shrubs, as if calculated to afford fuel for the weary, and care-warn traveler. We here found first rate feed, and good water. The snow caped mountains have been in sight all day.
Tuesday 6 To day we remained in camp. Some of our men during the day made a raft, on which we were to float our waggons and provisions across the river. Some spent a portion in baking, others in prospecting for gold along the bank of the river. They found gold, but in small quantities. I spent the most of the day in mending our tent. Thus passed this notable day.
Wednesday 7th Our raft not being made right, we spent the day in remodeling it, and rafting our waggons and provisions across the river. This was the most difficult task we have had to perform on our rout. The current of the river was strong and rapid our raft was floated across it, only by hard labor & good management

To day we passed 4 graves.
Saturday 3rd At 7 we rolled on a distance of 8 miles to the big sandy where we stoped 2 hours for the  mules to graze We then traveled on 18 miles when we again struck the big dandy. We here camped to spend the Sabbath. To day we padded 2 graves.
Sunday 4th We spent the day in conversation, reading visiting () At 6 our Captain gave us a good exhortation. This seemed to add cheerfulness & sincerity to all present' it caused us to feel that we were in a land of civilization
Monday 5th At 7 we harnessed our mules and began the new born week, by rolling on toward our place of destination. Though we were traveling down the west side of the Mountain, till our road was comparatively level and smooth. Interesting and curious shaped Bluffs, nearly bounded our road on each side. At noon we halted by the road side where there was neither wood nor water. At 1 p.m. we again moved on. Having traveled 12 miles we reached green river & rolled up its banks about 2 miles and camped for the night. Our camping

been various. A part was good others sandy. We also had several steep and strong hills to climb and descent. We passed 1 grave.
Saturday 19th Our train started at the usual time, and traveled at more than usual speed. I rode about 1/4 of a mile off the road to an Indian village where I traided one of my blankets for a buffalo robe. I remained here till the train had got considerable in advance of me so that I had to nearly all the forenoon to overtake it. This day our road was the most hilly of any on our rout thus far. At night we camped on the of Bear river. We have found wood, and good feed. To day we passed 7 graves.
Sunday 11th This being the Lords day we did not leave camp. Our company spent the day in various ways. Some were fishing. Some hunting, others in reading, conversation & meditation. Indians passed and repassed nearly all day. We were troubled considerable by their calling at our tents and urging for something to eat, to braid () This has

Thursday 8th We spent the forenoon in cooking riging and loading our waggons () At 1 p.m. we caught and harnessed our mules and again moved on over hills, and through vallies we trudged along in many places high steep bluffs bordered our road on each side, in others, our road lay on large and level tracts. About 3 p..m. I and 3 others road ahead of the train, supposing our Captain to be still in advance of us. We rode till after sun-set when finding our too far ahead of the train to go back to meet it & giving up all hopes of the trains overtaking us, we rode to a strangers camp and obtained lodging for the night. We passed 4 graves this afternoon.
Friday 9th I left my hospitable friend at 1/2 past 7 a.m. and rode on about 3 miles where I found grass (about 1/4 of a mile from the road) and let my mule graz till the train overtook me. I then traveled with them. We camped at noon as usual. After our usual nooning we rolled on, till night. We then camped on the bank on the bank of Sam's Forks ( a branch of green river)  The road to day has

blood. To day we passed three graves.
Thursday 13th At 7 a.m. we rolled out of camp. At noon we halted as usual. At 1 p.m. we were found again on the road. We drove along at more than usual speed till 6 p.m. when we camped in a beautiful red cedar grove. The road to day has been generally good. Some places it was level; some moderately undulating, others hilly. We have passed a variety of bluffs, which bounded the road on each side. They added beauty & interest to our journey. To day we passed 7 graves.
Wednesday 14th At the usual hours we again renewed our journey (One mile and a half from camp, we say a Soda Spring which is the greatest curiosity I had ever seen before. It is situated in a rocky Bluff about 30 feet in highth, and flows the top of a small conic shaped rock, about 3 feet high. Its waters are strongly pregnated with Soda) not purposing to travel far to day we did not falt at noon, but drove till 4 p.m. when we camped in a valley about 1 mile from the main road. Wood and water was good and plenty. We passed 2 graves.
