been the most (solessrn) day to me that I have seen since I left hoe. Nothing but experience can teach any one my feelings. Surely the western plains is the place to try mens souls. The fatigue and length of the journey, the exposure to a variety of weather in a strange climate, and the absence of civilized society, all tended to iritate, and beget within the human heart partial inhumanity and despreation. But God, the Author of the Universe who knows many hearts can comfort the weary traveler; even in this land of desolation.
Monday 12th At 8 a.m. we again moved on. Our road for a distance of 8 miles was good. We then reached the toll bridge at Thomas Fork. The road for 11 miles after crossing the fork was very rough and mountainous. We then struck Bear river where the road was comparatively level. It being 3 p.m we halted and graced our mules. At 5 we again rolled until near sun-set, when we camped in a valley near a small stream of water. Here musquetoes were so numerous, and the keen demands of their appitites so great, that we were obliged to fight or lose a portion of our

July
Thursday 15th at 7 a.m. we rolled out of camp. At a rapid pace we trudged along over lofty hills and though deep vallies till midday when we camped for noon in a valley on the shore of mud creek. At 1 1/2 p.m. we again moved on till dark. We then camped on hill near

About 1 1/2 miles from camp we saw a soda spring. This is something in the works of nature that fills the mind of the Beholder with wonder and admiration It is situated on a rock (which stands in the valley) abut 20 feet from its base. The water flows from the top of conic rock about 3 feet high. Its waters is strongly pregnated with Soda, though perfectly pure. 3/4 of a mile farther on  we saw a beer spring, so called from its water being prenated with leer or something with a similar taste (probably gass) 1/2 mile farther, on the bank of Bear rivers, we saw steamboat spring. This, if possible exceeds the other. It is situated on the brink of Bear River and in an exceeding romantic and interesting spot. It boils from a solid rock and has the appearance of a boiling pot. The water is often thrown in drops and small columes to a highth of from three to six feet. It is warm, and strongly pregnated with soda.

where we found good grass and plenty of it. At an early hour our Captain ordered friend ((Matthewan)) & I to eat a cold supper & take our blankets & repair to the mountains to watch the mules (It being our turns to wach) We accordingly took our bed clothes, a piece of bacon, some rice, biscuit & crackers and started. Having arrived, we built a fire & cooked our suppers. After supper we made our bed in the open air, and waited for midnight when we were to begin our task. About 10 o clock a four or two legged mountaineer ran through one ((level)) and created a stampede. As the frightened drove approached the spot where we were sleeping their noise waked me and I had just to rise & turn their course or should have been run over. We then in company with the guard for the forepart of the night carefully searched for the intruding stranger but did not find him. As soon as the mules became quiet we returned to bed. At midnight we were aroused to commence our duty; which we did and continued till 6 Sunday morning. We passed this day 8 graves.

a ravine in which there was water & plenty of wood. During the day we forded several small streams. To day we passed 2 graves.
Friday 16th At 7 a.m. we caught our mules & again started on our journey. 1 miles from cape we crossed the will muddy creek. This is a small stream whose banks are thickly covered with growing willows, and are also extremely soft & muddy. 8 miles farther we reached gravel creek. Here we camped for noon. Feed was poor & wood scarce. At 2 p.m. we broke camp and moved onwards' till near sun set when we camped in a valley where there was no water & but little wood. In the afternoon our road was tolerable good, we asscended & descended a lofty hill or mountain in one the slope was graduel the other was steep and very stony. Today we passed 1 grave.
Saturday 19th At 1/2 past 6 we rolled out of camp over lofty hills and through deep ravines we trudged along (halting at noon as usual) till 6 p.m. we then camped by the roads side near a spring of good water. The feed in or near camp being very poor we were obliged to take our mules one mile from camp in a ravine

we find the reminants of waggons harness & scores of dead cattle and occasionally a dead mule or horse lay along the road side.
Tuesday 21st At 7 a.m. we struck our tents & moved on, till noon. We then as usual, stopped and grazed our mules. At 1 p.m. we again started. Over an undulating road we tugged along little thinking that bad luck is liable to overtake the weary traveler in all places. About  ((8)) p.m. the skanes of one end of the fore axle of No 4 broke. We were thus disabled in a barren land, with nothing to mend the broken. But as luck would have it one of our boys found on an old camping ground, the very article we needed. We then found a suitable place, and camped; The cripled waggon was then taken in hand & ere day light had gone, it was ready to roll on. Our road to day has been good. The weather hot & we passed 1 grave.
Wednesday 21st At an early hour we left camp. During the forenoon we passed a variety of scenery; among which was Pyramid circle. It consist of multitudinous rocks, ranging fro 10 to 15

Sunday 18th We remained in cape. Our mules being a distance from camp some of the company (as their turns came) were obliged to watch them; while others spent most of the day in cooking. I spent nearly all day in the tent having done my duty in the mess in the morning. Our road for several days, has been truly romantic. Lofty mountains of various shapes, deep ravines, and shady groves of Poplar bound it on each side, small streams, bordered with thrifty growing wills, occasionally cross it & often for miles follow along its side, then suddenly disappears behind the mountains. O, there is wisdom and grandeur displayed in the works of Nature!
Monday 19th At 7 a.m. we struck our tents & began another weeks travel toward our place of destination. Our road in the forenoon was somewhat undulating & lay mostly between 2 chains of mountains. At noon we halted at the entrance of a large valley. We traveled all the afternoon in the valley & camped for at night near raft river with plenty of water but no wood. The road was first rate, descending nearly all the way. Today we passed 3 graves. We have now come to a region where

we moved on a distance of 9 miles and camped in hot spring valley. This valley is so called from the numerous hot springs (It is sometimes called thousand spring valley from the cause (this valley also contains a number of cold springs) Wood and water in camp to night is scarce. 2 graves to day
Saturday 24th At 7 a.m. we rolled out of camp. About 10 we passed a number of hot springs.They are scattered over about one acre of land, and are hot enough to boil eggs. At noon we halted on a hill side whe feed was tolerable, sage plenty,, but no water. After noon we traveled over an undulating road till about 5 o clock, we then camped in a large beautiful valley where feed was first rate, water and wood very scarce. The day has been very hot. The road very dusty. 1 grave to day
Sunday 25th This Lord's day we also spent in came. At 1 p.m. our Captain addressed us in the language of exhaustation. His remarks were appropriate & profitable. I felt benefited by them.
Monday 26th At 6 we rolled out of camp. Nothing of note transpired during the day but we moved on

feet in highth of various shapes tapering from the ground to the top. On these rocks are written the names of thousands of travelers. At noon we halted in a valley and graced our mules. At 1 p.m. we again rolled on to Goose creek, where we camped for night. Our road to day has been very rough. We asscended all day. We passed 2 grave.
Thursday 22nd At the usual hour we packed sack and baggage & at more than usual speed traveled toward our place of destination.. At noon we halted as usual. Four miles from our camp at noon, we left goose creek, and traveled 12 miles to spring valley. It being 10 p.m. when we arrived, we of course camped. Our road to day has been generally good. It runs over hills, 4 mountains, & through vallies, through deep ravines ) 1 grave to day.
Friday 23rd Feed being poor we harnessed and started without breakfast. After driving 4 miles we found tolerable feed. we here stopped cooked our breakfast & grazed the mules. After breakfast we rolled on (weather very hot) At noon we stopped where there was no wood nor water. Having nooned our usual time

Two of our men are now sick though not dangerously. 1 grave today.
Thursday 29th We left camp at the usual hours. Our course lay chiefly along the river (During the forenoon we passed through a deep & interesting ravine. Mountains of rocks of curious shapes stood bold & permanent on each side of the road as if to protect it & those who chance to travel it from invading foe. At noon we camped by the river and in consequence of sickness we remained in camp        the remainder of the day. The weather is very hot & the road extremely dusty. 2 graves to day.
Friday 30th The sick being a little better we rolled out of camp at an early hours. Our road in the forenoon was extremely stone, dusty & hilly. In the afternoon it was nearly level, less stony, but still dusty.       Our travel in the afternoon was in the valley of the Humbolt. We are now traveling in a somewhat interesting and romantic region. The mountains

unmolested by every species of trouble. Soon after leaving the valley in which we were camped, we entered a deep ravine, about 4 miles in length. This is truly an interesting spot a little stream of pure water bounded by thrifty growing willows gayly flows through it & 2 large warm springs come rustling from the foot of the mountain. Having reached the end of the ravine, we entered another beautiful and fertile valley in which we saw acres of wild & thrifty growing rye. We traveled in this valley till 6 p.m. when we camped on the Humbolt river. Wood scarce, water plenty, grass good. We passed two graves to day.
Tuesday 27th At 6 a.m. we renewed our journey. Our course to day, lay along the Humbolt, through the same fertile valley, we traveled yesterday. Some of our company to day began to feel unwell & complain of extreme pain. 3 graves to day.
Wednesday 25th Still we are traveling in the beautiful valley of the Rio Humbolt. feed is good, wood scarce, water tolerable... At night we camped in the same valley.

clear & current rapid. It also abounds in fish; but they are not easily caught.
Sunday August 1st In view of one being in an unhealthy region, our Captain thought it best to travel toward our place of destination. This we accordingly did. Through the rich and beautiful valley of the Humbolt (halting at noon) asusual) till near 5 p.m. when we forded the river & camped on its south bank. The weather is hot & roads good.
Monday 2nd We rolled out of camp at 5 a.m. During the forenoon we passed through the last canyon that lay on our road between the Sierra Madra, & Sierra Nevada. At noon we halted as usual. Having moved our usual length of time we again rolled out through the wide and noble valley of the Humbolt till night. We then camped by the river side where feed was torable but wood scarce. We passed 15 graves, nearly all of which

are less lofty. The vallies wider & feed better; than that we met with a few days ago. We have reached a region where the mountains are not so lofty as to think it beneath them to wear any other than snow white caps of the same color of their foundation. At night we camped by the side of the flowing Rio Humbolt. The days travel did not prove beneficial to the sick in the train.
Saturday 31st At 6 a.m. we rolled on . One mile & 1/2 from camp we forded the river. At noon we camped by the river side, feed first rate. Having nooned our usual time we moved on till night; when we again camped in the beautiful valley of the Humbolt. The sick today is a little better. We are now traveling in a valley so wide that the eye cannot reach across it. It abounds in grass wild sage, wild grain, willows ((SC)) It is watered by the swift flowing Humbolt, whose waters are

camped in the rain, without wood or feed & retired to bed without supper.
Thursday 5th In view of the scarcity of feed for our mules we packed bag & jack at an early hours and with out breakfast rolled on a distance of 3 miles where we found some grass. There we cooked our breakfast & stayed till 11 a.m. giving our animals time to graze & rest. At 11 we again began to move over the sandy plain. The country here presents barrenness and desolation on every hand. Little else than wild sage & greese wood can be seen growing on its sandy surface. To day some of our mules began to lag. Old Charley came near giving out entirely. We camped about six p.m. about 200 yards from the river. Grass tolerable. Wood scarce. The health of the company is good except Mr Thronton, who is now sick with the mountain fever. One grave today.
Friday 6th At 7 a.m. we threw the leather on our rassle jacks and again

had been dug open and the bones of some who had been laid there exposed to view. They had (no doubt) been opened by Indians in search of plunder.
Tuesday 3rd. We struck our tents at an early hour and again moved toward the end of our journey. The road was excessively dusty & in some places for miles the sane was from four to eight inches deep. Our mules labored hard to draw their loads. The region through which we passed to day is barren & unpleasant little else than wild sage & greese wood grows in its sandy surface. At night we camped about 3/4 of a miles from the road by the river side. Feed was tolerable & wood scarce. One grave today.
Wednesday 4th At an early hour we pulled up stakes & rolled on Over an extremely sandy & dusty & rough road we rolled along over bluffs & through valleys we moved along with eyes filled with dust and clothes covered with the same till 9 p.m. when we

it lies the big meadows which so often cheers the hearts of the care worn travelers. Here they may rest & recuit their teams and prepare for the troubles common to the latter end of the rout.
Sunday 8th This beautiful & pleasant day of The Lord we spent (till 3 PM) in preparing for our journey across the 50 mile desert At 3 PM all thing being ready we moved o n about dusk we reached a traiding post situated at the edge of the desert. We here watered our teams and rolled on, choosing rather to travel over the desert in the night than under the scorching rays of the sun. We had not traveled far on the desert when one of our boys picked up a human skull. Several of us examined it, and felt to sympathise with its unlucky owner. about 9 in the evening one of the wheels of waggon No 4 (the waggon belonging to my mess) ran off. We now found ourselves involved in trouble. We looked a long while

staggered toward the land of excitement. Through deep & burning sand from 4 to 10 inches deep we tugged along through a barren region till 3 p.m  when we reached the valley of the Humbolt. We then halted & let our animals graze; after which we rolled on a distance of about 3 miles and camped.
Saturday 7th We spent fore part of the day in cutting grass & drying it to carry on the desert for our animals. About 10 a.m. our Captain called the company together to hear their minds on the propriety of excusing three of our number who wished to leave the company & pack through the rest of the journey. By a vote of the company three mules and their portion of the property were given them & they were excused. (Their names A & J Steward & J Loux) At noon we pulled up stakes & rolled on till night when we camped in the same valley. This is an extensive valley situation on the sink of the Humbolt. In

making up our minds to pack our mules and go ahead. But a second thought ran over our brains. We again raised the axle, put the wheel on & took a nut from the hind axle & put in the pace of the last one, and put the leather one on the hind axle. Hope again revived and we moved on. At 3 1/2 a.m. Monday we overtook the rest of the train which had halted to feed their teams. Some of the grass they had brought with them. We of course followed suit. At 4 a.m. we moved on at distance of 3 or 4 miles where we stopped & cooked our breakfast & gave our teams the remainder of our grass & a little water from our water cags. Day light having returned we could plainly see the marks of misery & distruction that had gone before us. The ruins of waggons; cattle & horses without number met our eyes on every side. About 9 a.m. we reached a region of deep & heavy sand

in the dark for the nut but could not find it. Friend Matthewson then consented to take the heal of his boot to supply the place of the lost nut. A holes then bored through it the size of the screw on the end of the skane on which it was placed. Being thus temprorally righted up we again rolled on; but soon the leather nut came off, and down went the axle. We looked a short time for the lost heel, but did not find it. Friend M then offered his other book as a sacrafice to the luck and chance of a journey on the desert. Having put the other boot heel in the place of a nut, we again moved a head; but soon a crash was heard and down went the axle the 3rd time. On examination we found that the boxes in the wheel were broken. We now began to think we should be obliged to pack our mules and leave the waggon but luck often cheers the traveler. We realized our condition in a desert land, and were about

recruiting ourselves & animals as far as time and circumstances would admit. At 3 PM two of our boys took 8 mules and went on the desert after the waggon that was left. They returned with it at 10 in evening
Wednesday 11th At 7 AM we again pulled up stakes & rolled onward. At 1 PM we stopped & let our mules graze there being no grass nearer than sixteen miles of this place. After an intermition of 2 hours we rolled on over a very stony road till near sunset. We then camped on the bank of Carson river in the valley of the same name. We now being to feel near our journeys end. Having less than 150 miles to travel yet. We passed 15 graves to day. Our teams though they have seen some hard times look comparatively well. The health of the company is good except Mr. Thomaston who is still struggling with the mountain fever but his is gradually mending

August
We here found it necessary for all except the driver to travel on foot. Slowly and laboriousilly we trudged along through the burning sand (occasionally passing a traiding post, erected for the relief of the suffering traveler) till 10 AM when the cam of No 2 gave out and we were obliged to leave the waggon. The team, and the remainder of the train, then moved on till about 1 PM when we reached Carson Valley through which runs a beautiful river of the same name. We here watered our thirsty mules and drove about 1 1/2 miles down the river where we camped. At the entrance of this valley is situated a number of large traiding posts where various articles of refreshment are kept for sale, though at an exorbitant price. I purchases a small bottle of pickles for $1,50. 12 graves to day.
Tuesday 10th This day we remained in camp. We spent the day mostly in

Saturday 14th At 7 AM we again packed bag and sack and tackled rassle jack  and with different feelings and a variety of opinions we rolled toward our place of destination. The road was more or less sandy. At 11 AM we passed over a steep and sandy Bluff and landed in the  most beautiful valley I ever saw. About 150 yards to the right of the road as it enters the valley is situated a splendid grove of lofty pines (in which we camped to spend the remainder of the day and the Sabbath) This looked indeed like civilization in the wilderness. The valley is bounded on the N.N.W. by a smooth & barren mountain; on the S by

August
Thursday 12th At the usual hour we rolled out of camp and made progress toward our journeys end. Our course lay chiefly along the bank of the river. During the day we passed several small traiding posts. At night we camped in the valley under the shade of thrifty growing cotton-wood trees. This valley abounds in grass willows & cotton wood trees.
Friday 13th At the usual hour we again started. At noon we camped near a traiding post where one of our buys exchanged some bacon for pork. This we found to be a rarity. During the afternoon we passed a canyon in which there was several miners at work. It was said that they avariged $50 per day. We also passed 3 traiding posts and crossed an 8 mile desert. At night we again camped in Carson Valley, near another traiding post where we exchanged some bacon for beef. This we also considered as quite a treat.

August
road increased in steepness as we advanced, we found it necessary to pack our riding mules with valises, provisions ( ) from the waggons to make it more easy for our teams to climb the mount before them. All day we tugged up the mountain over a crooked and sandy road. I carried a heave stone nearly all the way to block the wheel when we stopped to let our teams rest.About sunset we reached the summit. Then moved 1 1/2 miles farther and camped. This days travel ranks among the most interesting though the hardest and most difficult of any on our route thus far. Though we were rising higher at every step we could look in all directions and see peaks far above us. On the summit of these mountains it is so cold that an over coat would not be a burden.

one of a more irregular shape on which is thrifty growing pine and fir trees. About 1 mile from the entrance may be seen a beautiful little lake whose unrippled waters lie sparkling in the rays of firy faced Sol. A reflecting mind while viewing this lake hemed in by lofty mountains may learn a lesson that would be a benefit to the petulent and fretful. A lesson on composure & contentment, that might touch the case of the whole of the human race. This valley also affords grass in abundance.
Sunday 15th We remained in camp till 4 1/2 PM. We than packed and moved distance of 5 or 6 miles up the valley and again camped. 
Monday 16th At an early hour we again started for the land of Gold. At 7 M we reached the foot of the Sierra Nevada. For awhile we tugged up the mountain side, but finding the

August
The shore of the mountain lake. There being a little grass here, we halted and let our mules graze. This being done we again rolled on toward the foot of the mount. Night came & we camped (on another grassy spot) for the night. Our road to day has been very rough a somewhat difficult.
Thursday 19th We started at the usual hour, and slowly made our way (over one of the worst roads I sever saw) down the mountain. At 1 PM we reached grass balled and camped for the rest of the day. This is a beautiful valley surrounded by snow capped mountains. whose sides abound in lofty pines and cedars it afforded an abundance of grass & good water.
Friday 20th At 6 1/2 AM we again harnessed our mules & again began to climb the mount. Soon we came to what we called the 1/2 miles pitch. It is very steep and stony & it was with some difficulty that we asscended it. Having reached the desirable end of this half miles we again began

August
Tuesday 17th To day we remained in camp on the top of the mountains; plenty of snow in sight, and too much cold wind for convenience or comfort. Mr B's train not being able to reach the summit yesterday some of our boys with three of our teams (for B's were about used up) and went and helped him to the summit. Others with guns in had and blood in their eyes went a hunting for grizzly bears, deer () But they found no game. In the morning I shot twice at a wolf. The first time I muffed him, the 2nd hit him in the same place. Sol at length sank behind the mount & we straitened ourselves on our pallets, shut or lookers for another nights sleep.
Wednesday 18th At 7 we pulled up stakes and rolled along. Over vexatious rocks, through the brush & down the mountain side, we tugged along till we reached a nearly level spot of earth, situated on

hour and rolled along over lofty mountains and through deep ravines (and over a road that is bad enough to make a child strike his father) till 1 PM when we reached a better and more level piece of road. 5 miles farther on we passed a traiding post where we purchased some salt, cheese ( ) 3 miles farther we camped for the night. Thus far good luck has followed us.
Monday 23rd At the usual hour we started with life and energy purposing to finish our journey before night. Having traveled 8 miles we reached a traiding post, we have camped and drove our mules 1 1/2 miles on a ranche where we were to give $3 a piece for month. We were to remain in camp till our Captains return from Colona.
Tuesday 24th We are still laying on our ears. Nothing to note has transpired during the day - our Captain not having returned we are still obliged to remain in camp.
Wednesday 25th The day passed with us the same as yesterday.

August
to descend over one of the most God forsaken waggon breaking mule provoking driver perplexing heart sickening roads I ever saw. Over rocks & down short & steep pitches over logs & through mud nearly deep enough to take a mule in out of sight, we pushed along fully determined that the Sierra Nevada should not conquer the NY boys. Night came & we again turned in. The feed was good.
Saturday 21st At the usual hour we again moved on. Our traveling to day was up and down the mountain as it had been for days before. The road still extremely rough, the mountains high and steep. While on the mount top we see huge banks of snow far below us. Night came and we, tired and hungry camped in ravine where there was water, but no grass. The mountains are covered with large and thrifty growing pines & cedars.
Sunday 22nd Our provisions having run short, we were compelled to travel. We accordingly started at an early

August 1852
Sunday 29th This Lords day I spent at the forest house. Here there is but little chance for retirement or meditation. The bustle of week day business is carried on the same as other days regardless of the Sabbath. All seem to have forgotten the divine command "Remember the Sabbath to keep it holy"  GOLD is the object of every man and the best means of obtaining it is their aim and study.
Monday 30th About 10 AM I went to Yankee Pines and spent the rest of the day. Nothing of note transpired within my observation. The Town was thriving with the active business of life. At night I returned to the forest house.
Tuesday 31st I spent the forenoon at the forest house. This is a rude looking house, built for the accomodation of miners & travelers. Lofty pines & cedars surround it on every side. After noon I went to Volcano bar; a distance of 2 miles situated on the middle for of the American river. Here may be seen the eagerness with which men are seeking for Gold. The marks of untiring indust-

Thursday 26th We still remain in camp. Nothing of note has transpired to day.
Friday 27th We spent the day in dividing the company stock. This occupied the whole day. The amount falling to each man is one hundred Dollars & ninety one cents. Our company has now disbanded, and begins to scatter. We no doubt shall never meet again.
Saturday 28th Our company is disbanded and some has already gone in different directions seeking their fortunes. At 6 AM I in company with ((yis) mess started for Yankee Pines ( a distance of 8 or 10 miles) ON our way, we stopped at the forest house and took breakfast. We here left our baggage & went on our way and reached the Town about 11 AM. My business there was to sell my mules which I did as soon as possible; I then in company with 3 others returned to the forest house ^ stopped for the night.

September 1852
-try meet the eye of the beholder in every direction. Near sunset myself & two others started on our return.Night overtook us before we had gone far up the hill. We then had to climb a very steep and difficult hill in the dark. About 8 PM we reached the forest house and put up for the night.
Wednesday Sept 1st I remained at the forest house all day. I spent the forenoon in repairing my clothes regulating the contents of my valises. Afternoon I studied head work, read the news ( )
Thursday 2nd In the morning friend Steward & I went to Yankee Pines and borrowed some mining tools and prospected a portion of devils Canyon. We found gold in several places. At length we became tired & returned to the Hotell where we put up for the night.
Friday 3rd After breakfast we went to Volcano bar to see what the business prospect was; finding business dull, we returned to the forest house and turned in for the night
